awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Mechanistic studies of the spore photoproduct lyase
awd_abstract_narration:
Two endospore-forming bacterial strains (Clostridium botulinum and Bacillus anthracis) are Category A bioterrorism agents. Their endospores are extremely resistant to UV irradiation. This highly unusual UV resistance is ascribed to the formation of a special DNA photo-lesion called the spore photoproduct (SP), and the efficient repair of SP by the enzyme spore photoproduct lyase (SPL). The pursuit of the reaction mechanism of SPL may allow the selective targeting of the SP repair process to kill spore-forming bacteria via UV irradiation, improving human health and national security. This pursuit will also permit graduate, undergraduate, and high school students to acquire specialized training in DNA photochemistry and mechanistic enzymology. Additionally, female and underrepresented minority high school students will be targeted for enhanced chemistry education by establishing the Hoosier High School Chemistry Olympiad Training Camp.

With this award, the Chemistry of Life Processes Program in the Chemistry Division is funding Dr. Lei Li from Indiana University-Purdue University Indianapolis to establish the presence of a novel radical transfer pathway in spore photoproduct lyase (SPL) and understand its role in facilitating the regeneration of the S-adenosylmethionine (SAM) cofactor at the end of each catalytic cycle. Unnatural amino acids will be utilized to help characterize the putative radical species along the pathway. Fluorescent nucleotide analogs and hydrogen/deuterium exchange mass spectrometry will be adopted to probe the respective DNA and protein conformational changes during SPL catalysis. The proposed studies will provide the much-needed information to reveal the requirements enabling SAM regeneration in SPL. As SAM regeneration is indicated in many other enzymes in the so-called radical SAM superfamily (> 56,000 members), the proposed studies are of great significance to our understanding of not only SPL, but also the other enzymes in the superfamily.

por.por_cntn:
Two endospore-forming bacterial strains (Clostridium botulinum and Bacillus anthracis) are responsible for serious infectious diseases botulism and anthrax respectively. Although Ultraviolet is commonly used for disinfection in public space, it does not work effectively against these endospores because spores are 10-100-fold more resistant to UV irradiation. This highly unusual UV resistance is ascribed to the formation of a special DNA photo-lesion called the spore photoproduct (SP), and the efficient repair of SP by the enzyme spore photoproduct lyase (SPL). The pursuit of the reaction mechanism of SPL may allow the selective targeting of the SP repair process to kill spore-forming bacteria via UV irradiation. Additionally, our earlier studies showed that SPL contains a unique electron transfer pathway that is critical for the enzyme's catalytic function. Electron transfer is an essential process in nature; our SPL studies also contribute to the understanding of this important life process.

 

Under the support of the NSF CAREER award from the Chemistry of Life Processes Program, our group conducted investigations on the SP chemistry and biochemistry with a focus on the mechanistic understanding of the repair enzyme - the spore photoproduct lyase in the past 6 years. Our research led to a few surprising findings during the SP formation and repair processes as highlighted below.

 

Our research found that the SP lesion in the middle of a duplex DNA strand is a surprisingly poor substrate for SPL.  To the best of our knowledge, this represents an unprecedented example of a major DNA repair enzyme that cannot effectively repair its substrate lesion within the normal DNA conformation adopted in growing cells. Factors such as other DNA binding proteins, helicases or an altered DNA conformation may cooperate with SPL to enable efficient SP repair in germinating spores. Therefore, both SP formation and SP repair are likely to be tightly controlled by the unique cellular environment in dormant and outgrowing spore-forming bacteria, and thus SP repair may be extremely slow in non-spore-forming organisms.

 

Our research has indicated that unprecedented electron transfer pathway involved in SPL catalysis is composed of at least one active-site cysteine and two tyrosine residues. Such an electron transfer process would require the protein to adopt relatively flexible conformation, to enable the interaction of the key amino acid residues during the catalytic process. In collaboration with Prof. Michael Gross's group at the Washington University in St. Louis, we adopted the cutting-edge hydrogen/deuterium exchange mass spectrometry (HDX MS) technology to analyze the SPL conformation during catalysis. Our data confirmed that the conserved cysteine is located at a highly flexible loop region. Results from the kinetic isotope effect studies conducted by our group also support this conclusion. SPL indeed possesses a flexible active site and readily undergoes conformational changes during catalysis.

 

Besides the SPL-mediated SP repair, we also collaborated with Prof. Stefan Stoll's group as the University of Washington in Seattle, utilizing the sophisticated electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectroscopy to shed light on the SP formation process. SP formation has been proposed to proceed through a radical pair intermediate. Using a series of isotopically labeled thymidine molecules, we indeed observed that in microcrystals, thymidine molecules exposed to UV radiation produce these two radical species. Additionally, we identified three sources which may donate the additional hydrogen in the formation of a radical. This lends support to the radical pair intermediate hypothesis in the SP formation.

 

The NSF grant support also allows us to contribute to the national DEI mission in STEM research. Diversity of personal experiences, culture, and perspectives drives the innovation and creativity needed to meet the most pressing challenges at the frontier of scientific research and education. The current lack of female and minority STEM researchers requires the attention from the whole scientific community. The CAREER award allows the PI to support a minority female graduate student since the beginning of her graduate studies, creating an excellent environment for her and enabling her to focus on the cutting-edge research from the very first days.
